title: City news: John Lewis, Argos, Lloyd’s and NEXT
text:
City news: John Lewis, Argos, Lloyd’s and NEXT City news: John Lewis, Argos, Lloyd’s and NEXT JOHN Lewis Partnership suffered a 26 per cent drop in half-year profit as higher pension costs and a fierce supermarket price war took their toll. PUBLISHED: PUBLISHED: 00:01, Fri, Sep 11, 2015 GETTY Profits are down at John Lewis 
The employee-owned business said same-store sales at Waitrose were down 1.3 per cent, its first fall for seven years, after “exceptionally tough” conditions in the grocery market caused by falling prices and changing customer shopping patterns. 
Its department stores lifted like-for-like turnover by 3 per cent as overall group sales rose 2.1 per cent to £5.1billion. 
However, pre-tax profit before exceptional items dropped 26 per cent to £96million and the group predicted annual profit could fall by more than 20 per cent due to a £60million higher pension charge. 
John Lewis chairman Sir Charlie Mayfield said: “At a trading level our profits were broadly level with last year despite the turmoil in the grocery market.” 
He expects Waitrose and the department stores to perform “comparatively well against the market”. Dixons sales up on Argos 
DIXONS Carphone tightened its grip on Britain’s consumer electricals market with bumper quarterly sales as rival Argos continued to struggle. Related articles John Lewis boosts partnerships with Rossopomodoro and Joe & The Juice 
The demise of Phones4U and Comet has boosted the fortunes of Dixons Carphone, which has enjoyed a big market share gain in phone sales as revenues in its UK and Ireland stores jumped 10 per cent. 
But Argos suffered a 2.8 per cent fall in like-for-like second-quarter sales after weaker demand for TVs and tablets, which more than offset a stronger performance in toys. 
Total sales fell 0.4 per cent to £897million. 
Argos parent company Home Retail Group’s DIY business, Homebase, enjoyed a 5.9 per cent rise in same-store sales over the same period. 
Home Retail chief executive John Walden said the outlook for Argos during the key festive trading period seemed “less predictable than usual due to a less certain promotional environment”. 
Its shares fell 8¾p to 140p, while Dixons Carphone rose 7½p to 427½p. Lloyd’s expects more takeovers 
THE boss of Lloyd’s of London expects more takeover deals at the 327-year-old insurance market as earnings are squeezed by fierce price competition. 
Amlin became the latest Lloyd’s insurer to be snapped up by an overseas predator this week in a £3.5billion takeover by Japan’s Mitsui Sumitomo, after the recent acquisitions of Catlin and Brit. Related articles Lloyd’s cautious in ‘benign’ year 
Lloyd’s chief executive Inga Beale said consolidation was a “natural outcome” of a lot of mature markets not seeing growth and Lloyd’s is seen as “a market leader” Lloyd’s said its half-year pretax profi t fell nearly 28 per cent to £1.19billion.
